Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Feasibility of a two-phase test tube assay for rapid detection and enumeration of Vibrio vulnificus and Vibrio parahaemolyticus in oysters
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will be the development of a detection assay to reduce the incidence of Vibrio-related infections. Infections from Vibrio parahaemolyticus and Vibrio vulnificus are the leading causes of seafood-borne infections and fatalities, respectively, and stem primarily from raw oysters. Development and implementation of rapid, accurate, inexpensive and easy-to-use testing methods would expand Vibrio data collection and enhance preventive measures by state shellfish labs (monitor harvest areas), and oyster processors and post-harvest processors (quality control at facilities). The assays will be available to users in simple, ready-to-prepare kits. These kits will make it easy for non-specialized personnel to test oyster lots still under refrigeration without disrupting logistics, and help U.S. oyster processors and post-harvest processors improve risk management tools and access export markets with restrictions on Vibrio levels. The tests also will improve environmental risk evaluations for harvest areas by state shellfish labs, FDA, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and other members of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program. The tests will be marketed in the U.S., and other large oyster producing nations.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop two-phase, thermostable test tube media formulations for the detection and enumeration of pathogenic V. parahaemolyticus, total V. parahaemolyticus, and V. vulnificus in oysters. The goal is to demonstrate a) > 95% sensitivity and specificity of each test with pure cultures and oyster samples; b) 24-hr detection time; c) ease-of-use of the ready-to-prepare kits, based on time, steps, equipment, materials and feedback from industry; and d) low cost. The main technical hurdles are: 1) Increasing formulation volumes for test tube assays since linear increases of agar layer volumes in test tube media formulations could impact Vibrio organism motility, and consequently detection speed and accuracy; and 2) replacing a non-heat stable antibiotic component, Polymixin B of the V. vulnificus test, with a heat stable alternative, like ampicillin or lincomycin, to improve ease-of-use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Secure Food Solutions (SFS) received funding from the National Science Foundation Small Business Technology Transfer Phase 1 program to demonstrate the feasibility of 2-phase test tube assays for rapid detection and enumeration of Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Vp) and Vibrio vulnificus (Vv) in oysters. These bacteria are the leading causes of seafood-related illness and fatality, respectively, in the US, primarily from raw oyster consumption. Chris Ramezanpour of SFS and Dr. Juan Silva of Mississippi State University (MSU) served as Co-PIs on the project.

The U.S. oyster industry grew nearly 75 percent from $103 M in 2005 to $180 M in 2013. During roughly that same time-period, Vibrio infections rose by 52 percent. The U.S. oyster industry needs a way to continue to grow while minimizing the risk of Vibrio infections. The rapid Vibrio tests evaluated during this project may provide a fast, easy and low-cost means for oyster harvesters and state shellfish labs to routinely monitor Vibrio levels in oyster samples in growing and harvest areas to support better predictive modeling tools and improved risk management for oyster zones, which would help minimize Vibrio infections and outbreaks, and their costs to the public and industry.

In the early stages of the project we learned that the enumeration requirements for a test tube-based assay would be economically and operationally impractical (a single test would require more than 2 dozen test tubes for a 3-tube dilution series for enumeration). In response to this discovery we adjusted the research plan to focus on the feasibility of a microplate format instead, in which detection and enumeration could be done in a single plate at a relatively low cost. Calibration and optimization of the microplate assays was performed at the SFS lab (Memphis, TN), as was stability testing. Oyster testing was performed at the SFS lab and the MSU lab (Starkville, MS).

During inclusivity and exclusivity testing with pure cultures, SFS calibrated components/concentrations of the enrichment broth and the agar layers of each microplate medium formulation to optimize sensitivity, specificity, time to detection, and ease of detection (i.e., chromogenic/color change). A total of 46 agents (and variations) were tested to improve performance of the Vibrio microplates, in 421 experiments. The results were high sensitivity (true positive) and specificity (true negative): Vp (total) - 100% sensitivity, 84% specificity; Vp (pathogenic) - 92% sensitivity, 100% specificity; and Vv - 86% sensitivity, 100% specificity. All three tests demonstrated 24-hour detection (no pre-enrichment required), and distinct color change for easy interpretation of presence/absence.

To enhance commercial feasibility of the tests SFS also achieved 14-day stability for all three tests, not just the Vv test. The tests previously only had a 3-hour stability once agar layers had been dispensed, which would have made them commercially impractical. The Vp (pathogenic) and Vv test results with the shelf-stable formulation were comparable to the original results; but the shelf-stable Vp (total) formulation showed reduced specificity.

Results were mixed with the oyster trials:  Vp (total) - 63% sensitivity, 50% specificity in treatments, and false positive issues in the control samples; Vp (pathogenic) - 100% sensitivity, 100% specificity in treatments, but a couple false positives in the controls; and Vv - 100% sensitivity, 100% specificity in treatments, but a significant number of false positives in the controls. Time to detection and ease of detection were comparable to results with pure cultures.
